generated_text: The structure of hydrate is a key factor in understanding the properties of the hydrate system. The structure of hydrate is also important for the application of hydrate in the fields of energy and environment. However, the structure of hydrate is still a mystery. In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and temperature. The structure of neon hydrate is similar to that of ice II, which is a unique structure of water.

We provide a categorical definition of quantum mechanics. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian species. Our results suggest that the extreme reduction in genome size and gene content in the Myxozoa was accompanied by a reduction in the complexity of the body plan. This is the first report of a genome size smaller than 100 Mbp in an animal. Our results provide insights into the origin of the Myxozoa and the evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic one. (Show more)

The study of the molecular mechanisms of viral antagonism is a key to understanding the mechanisms of viral persistence and the development of effective antiviral strategies. Here we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to antagonize the antiviral action of IFN by hijacking the Nup98-Rae1 complex. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the mechanisms of viral antagonism and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world will need to produce more food to feed a projected 10 billion people by the middle of the 21st century. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase in all major maize-producing and -exporting countries, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet composition. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the need for more comprehensive diet analyses in future studies of LMH coexistence. (Show more)

This study provides a snapshot of the financial health of small businesses in the early stages of the COVID-19 crisis. We find that many businesses are already facing closure, and that the financial fragility of small businesses is a major concern for policymakers. Our findings suggest that the CARES Act should be expanded to provide grants rather than loans, and that the program should be administered by the Small Business Administration rather than the Small Business Administration and the Treasury Department.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global scale of the problem is still debated. We show that the distribution of floating plastic debris in the open ocean is mostly concentrated in convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but that the total load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our results suggest that the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in science. The solar system is thought to have formed from the gravitational collapse of a molecular cloud. However, the origin of the molecular cloud is still a mystery. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is much younger than the age of the solar system. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This suggests that the solar system formed from the gravitational collapse of a molecular cloud. The results are consistent with the existence of a second generation of stars and the formation of the solar system from the gravitational collapse of a molecular cloud.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased exponentially. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries.

The ability to reproduce is the defining characteristic of all life on Earth. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also the most limiting factor in the evolution of placental mammals. We show that the ability to reproduce is limited by the mother’s metabolic power, and that this is the case across a wide range of species, including humans.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the inflammatory protease caspase-1, which is activated in the brain in response to inflammation, is also able to cleave α-syn at its C terminus, thereby promoting its aggregation. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to slow down the progression of MSA. This study also provides a rationale for the use of caspase-1 inhibitors in the treatment of other α-synucleinopathies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. This paper describes the nature of the communication network and its properties. The findings provide a better understanding of the endothelium and its role in the cardiovascular system. They also provide a foundation for future research on the endothelium and its role in cardiovascular disease. The findings may also have implications for other cell types that use similar communication networks.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of a data infrastructure, the COVIDcast API, that provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance systems. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We believe that this infrastructure will be useful to many stakeholders, including policy makers, epidemiological modelers, and researchers. We hope that the infrastructure and software will be useful to the research community and that the data will be useful for many applications.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this Threonine residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. It also provides a structural basis for the structural coupling between the closed state and the C-type inactivation state in K+ channels. This work is expected to be of interest to researchers in the fields of ion channels, structural biology, and protein engineering.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in the health of the host. However, the role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host is not well understood. One of the main reasons for this is that the gut microbiome is difficult to study. This study shows that anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome of herbivores synthesize a variety of natural products, which could be harnessed as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate in dyadic encounters, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches. (PsycINFO Database Record

The design of multifunctional structures with programmable and extreme responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to discover multifunctional structures with complex shapes and seamless material distributions that can precisely realize arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The proposed strategy can be extended to design multifunctional structures with programmable responses and can be applied to a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, is a key factor in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells. We show that IGF2BP1 is downregulated in fetal liver and that its overexpression results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern. This is achieved by a reduction in the expression of the alpha-globin gene, which is not affected by the change in the beta-globin gene expression. This study provides a mechanism for the chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. It also provides a potential target for the development of therapies for hemoglobinopathies. (Read more)

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis is frequently mutated in cancer, and that this mutation protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through a mechanism involving the induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1). This mechanism can be overcome by inhibiting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway, and we show that this combination therapy is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings provide a rationale for the development of new therapies for cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and its treatment is the most important strategy to prevent cardiovascular events. However, the use of antihypertensive drugs is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular events. This study provides a mechanism of action of a major class of antihypertensive drugs, which is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular events.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the policy was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. Our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The predicted best candidate is more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin. This study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. The approach presented here can be extended to other antibiotic classes and to other targets. This will enable the development of new antibiotics for the treatment of antibiotic-resistant infections. (PsycINFO Database Record

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales, and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful for many image-processing problems in the future.

The study of past climate variability is critical for understanding the present state of the climate system and for predicting future changes. This study presents a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The results show that the lake level dropped by more than 400 m during the last glacial cycle, and that the lake has been much lower than today for more than half of the last 1.3 My. The study also shows that the lake level was higher during the last glacial cycle than today, and that the lake has been much lower than today for more than half of the last 1.3 My. The study provides a unique insight into the processes that have shaped the Lake Malawi ecosystem and its biodiversity. The study also provides a unique insight into the processes that have shaped the Lake Malawi ecosystem and its biodiversity. View Full-Text

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime can have important biological effects on sleep, including a delay in the circadian clock, reduced melatonin levels, and reduced sleepiness. These effects may have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Holocene, but the cause of this cooling is still debated. One of the proposed causes is the impact of a bolide. We show that the osmium isotope composition of the Younger Dryas ejecta is consistent with a terrestrial origin.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been a matter of debate. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not as simple as previously thought.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles is driven by the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and that the origin of specialized herbivory in beetles coincides with the first appearance of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These findings have implications for understanding the origin of animal diversity and the evolution of plant-feeding habits.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. Our approach can be applied to engineering other protein molecules, such as vaccines, and can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work provides a promising strategy for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

This paper presents a large-scale experiment that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution. We show that, contrary to popular belief, larger populations do not enhance cumulative cultural evolution. Instead, we find that the size of the population may actually hinder cumulative cultural evolution. These results have implications for the evolution of technology in general, and for the evolution of culture in particular.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of APOE in AD and suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere that is 2,356 km in diameter and has a density of 12.0–12.9 g/cm3. It is the only solid sphere in the universe. The inner core is a mystery because it is not known how it formed. This paper provides a solution to the mystery.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain effects of marijuana are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain DA responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are attenuated in marijuana abusers, who also show higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction. These findings suggest that the attenuated brain DA responses to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers contribute to their addictive behaviors and negative emotionality.

Language is a uniquely human skill, enabling communication, culture, and civilization. The brain’s neural mechanisms for language processing are not well understood. Here, we show that a large family of artificial neural networks that optimize for accuracy on a widely used language prediction task predict brain responses to sentences in humans. These models’ brain scores and language predictions are correlated with each other and with behavioral performance. These results provide computational evidence for predictive processing in the human brain and suggest that predictive processing may underlie many aspects of language comprehension.

Deep learning has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is a consequence of the fact that deep learning is a special case of a more general problem. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where there are no algorithms that can compute stable solutions, even with a high probability of success. This is a fundamental result that will help us understand the limitations of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major challenge for science and society. It is also a major challenge for science and society. The scientific community is currently debating the extent to which the pandemic is a result of people’s inability to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that is often cited as evidence for this claim. It shows that the experiment’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time, and that they are a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two distinct bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-damaging disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the non-neuromuscular form of leprosy known as lepromatous leprosy. This study provides the first genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, and shows that the two bacteria have diverged little since their separation from a common ancestor. This finding suggests that the two bacteria are still capable of causing similar diseases, and may be the cause of the other.

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources for quantum information processing. They are also the two main ingredients of thermodynamics, which is the science of equilibrium statistical mechanics. Therefore, understanding the evolution of entanglement and entropy is key to understanding the evolution of thermodynamics. We show that the entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is exact in a scaling limit, and it is valid for both unitary and dissipative dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. This work is a major step toward the understanding of the evolution of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. The only vaccine currently available for use in humans is based on the inactivated virus, which has several limitations. In this study, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is being developed by our group. The vaccine is based on a segment of the spike protein, which is recoded with synonymous suboptimal codons, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine generates high levels of spike IgG antibodies and plaque reduction neutralization titers in hamsters. The vaccine is highly attenuated, and upon challenge with the wild-type virus, it protects hamsters from almost all SARS-CoV-2–associated weight loss. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred from the 14th to the 19th century, led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is poorly understood, with the assumption that it was predominantly spread by rats. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a Bayesian approach to model fitting, which allows for the inclusion of uncertainty in the model parameters. This approach is essential for the interpretation of epidemiological data and the development of models that can be used to understand the past and inform the future.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of neuroscience and a key topic in the history of science. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity, which is the ultimate goal of evolution, has been less studied. This study shows that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is also shaped by the evolution of the number of neurons. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of brain size and the evolution of animal intelligence.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. Some studies have suggested that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others have suggested that it is an oncoprotein. Here we show that TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that regulates the metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficient cells display enhanced invasiveness, and TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal component of cells, and their disassembly is essential for many cellular processes. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament disassembly. However, how it does so is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF binds to actin filaments and that this binding is enhanced by a mechanical torque. We propose that this mechanism is critical for ADF to efficiently sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of ADF’s function and may lead to the development of new therapies.

Fructose, a common sugar found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose, a sugar found in fruits and vegetables. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food, leading to a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Understanding the effects of different sugars on brain and behavior may help to develop strategies to reduce the risk of obesity and its comorbidities. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent and sex-biased colonization from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it will be useful for the study of human migrations and the study of human diversity in the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. Our results suggest that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. Our findings have implications for the design of social media platforms, as well as for the study of emotional contagion in the real world.

Messenger RNA sequences that are not involved in protein synthesis can also be modified. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA can change the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNA can have a modest impact on protein synthesis.

This study shows that a sense of worthwhile living is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and well-being, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. This result is consistent with the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven toward intermediate body sizes by the energetic demands of the aquatic environment.

The common cold is one of the most common reasons for seeking medical attention, yet there is no cure for the disease. The cold virus, rhinovirus, is the most common cause of the common cold, and it replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This study demonstrates that the cold virus replicates preferentially at cool temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings may help to identify new targets for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

This study demonstrates that the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor for the mechanical activity of the cell surface. This is a significant finding because it suggests that the pili are not only used for motility, but also for sensing the mechanical activity of the cell surface. This study also provides a mechanism for how the pili can be used for sensing the mechanical activity of the cell surface.

This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide problem. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is widespread and that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

This study provides evidence of the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, which could act as a reservoir for the virus. The findings also highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. This paper examines the problems associated with building large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions. We show that the benefits of hydropower are overestimated and the costs underestimated. We also show that the environmental and social impacts of dams are not being adequately addressed. We propose a new approach to hydropower that is more sustainable and can help the world meet its energy needs in a more environmentally friendly way.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the seventh leading cause of death in the United States. The disease is characterized by the presence of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, which are believed to be the result of sustained microglial activation. However, the earliest stages of the disease, when plaques are absent, are associated with a plaque-independent inflammatory response. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type responsible for the production of amyloid, are also the source of the earliest inflammatory response in AD. Our results suggest that the accumulation of soluble and oligomeric amyloid species in neurons may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in the history of agriculture. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation remains elusive. Here we present the results of a comprehensive survey of the chicken in the archaeological record. We show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens dates to the Hellenistic period in the Southern Levant, and that the species was already widely exploited in Europe by the first century B.C.E. These results provide new insights into the process of the adoption of chickens in European husbandry.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are not known for most proteins. This study provides a detailed view of the folding of a large protein, the maltose binding protein. The study provides a model for the folding of other proteins. The study also provides a model for the folding of proteins in general.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism of stress signaling in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap of Np4-capped RNAs is not the same as the one that removes the cap of 5′ RNA termini. This enzyme, which we identify as the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, prefers to remove capped RNA termini by a mechanism that is distinct from the one it uses to remove capped 5′ termini. This finding has implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress, as well as for the evolution of bacterial stress responses.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is a key player in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic agent for the restoration of immune function during sepsis. Our results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a better understanding of the mechanisms involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression and the potential of citrulline as a therapeutic agent for the restoration of immune function during sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants, is enormous. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are expected to be useful for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem and for the development of sustainable practices.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is used in many applications, such as in sensors and lasers. However, it is brittle and thus not used in many applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the metallization can be reversibly controlled by strain. This work opens up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is a rapidly developing field. This work is a contribution to this field, and it provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of a unique peptide. The structure of the peptide is largely disordered and dynamic, and it is stabilized by two disulfide bonds. The peptide exhibits potent fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens, and it binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides. The antifungal activity of the peptide is due to its ability to bind to the cell wall of the fungal pathogen and to the plasma membrane of the host plant. The antifungal activity of the peptide is due to its ability to induce reactive oxygen species and to penetrate the cell wall and the plasma membrane at discrete foci. The antifungal activity of the peptide is due to its ability to bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides. The antifungal activity of the peptide is due to its ability to penetrate the cell wall and the plasma membrane at discrete foci. The antifungal activity of the peptide is due to its ability to induce reactive oxygen species.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is dynamic after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is enriched with proteins that are transferred from the male to the female. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The von Willebrand factor (VWF) protein is a key player in the blood clotting system. Mutations in VWF cause a common disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD), which is characterized by bleeding. We show that the A1 domain of VWF can be switched between two states by force, which is a key feature of the blood clotting system. The force-switchable state is associated with faster binding kinetics, which is important for the function of VWF in the blood clotting system. This work provides a mechanism for the effects of mutations in VWF, which can be used to develop new therapies.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is the focus of intense study. The human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on humans, is a major component of this ecosystem, but it has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. We present a database of human-associated viruses, which is the most comprehensive to date. We also show that there are many associations between viruses and diseases, and that these associations are enriched for those that have been found in case-control studies. This database will be useful for both the study of the human microbiome and the study of viruses in general.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. This paper introduces a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The origin of life is one of the most fundamental questions in science. The temperature of Earth’s surface during the first few billion years of its existence is a key factor in the origin of life. This study provides a new method for reconstructing the temperature of Earth’s surface in the past, based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient organisms.

Ion channels are the main ion conduits in cells and are regulated by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that BK channel C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the regulation of K+ channels and may help in the development of new drugs.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2017 alone. The parasite exploits the host cell’s biophysical properties to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host erythrocyte, which in turn reduces a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the malaria parasite invasion process and opens up a number of exciting avenues for future research. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for many applications, but its properties can be improved further. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that the bandgap can be made to vanish. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Despite the availability of effective antiviral drugs and vaccines, the disease continues to cause significant burden to human health. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to influenza virus infection and disease severity. We further show that this effect is mediated, at least in part, by impaired mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral response, and tissue repair. Our study provides insights into the role of dry air in influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat influenza virus infection. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this structure is indirect. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the processing of sentences is consistent with a tree-like structure, with each word contributing to the construction of a phrase. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to build phrases from words, and that this operation is a fundamental component of the brain’s processing of language.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes, including cell fate determination, cell proliferation, and cell differentiation. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are functionally redundant, but they are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation may be used to fine-tune the function of Axin in different tissues.
This study provides a detailed characterization of a brain circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Symbiotic associations between plants and bacteria are the most abundant and ancient form of plant interactions. However, the majority of these associations are not beneficial to the plant, and many are detrimental. The development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis would allow the control of the nitrogen-fixing bacteria, which are the most important group of microorganisms that are responsible for the loss of soil fertility. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of nitrogen-fixing bacteria. This work is a significant step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis. (Show more)

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their senses to perceive the world around them. The sense of hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use, and the additional benefits of reducing other anthropogenic sources. We show that a phaseout of fossil fuels can save 3.6 million lives per year, and the additional reduction of nonfossil sources can save 5.6 million lives per year. The phaseout of fossil fuels can also restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global community. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the pandemic. Here we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale, with the potential to provide a cost-effective solution for the global community.

The study of the development of neural crest-derived tissues is a major challenge in biology. Here, we show that the zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling pathway is involved in the regulation of iridophore development. This study provides a link between the ALK/Ltk signaling pathway and the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex story that has been difficult to reconstruct due to the lack of ancient DNA evidence. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical period in the history of plague. Our results suggest that the emergence of plague was a gradual process, with a single lineage persisting for thousands of years without significant diversification. This study also reveals the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. These data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague and its early evolution. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. (PsycINFO Database Record

The agricultural intensification of grasslands has led to the release of carbon (C) to the atmosphere. This study shows that the adoption of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems can mitigate this trend. The most effective practices were those that incorporated legumes and manure into crop rotations, which increased the amount of carbon stored in the soil. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a pathway for climate-smart agriculture.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover to humans. The resulting ranking of 887 viruses, alongside a database of the viruses, provides a resource for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource will be of interest to a broad audience, including scientists, policy makers, and the general public.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the chemical basis for this color is poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this compound. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular framework for the study of the evolution of nectar chemistry. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 7th centuries AD. We show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestries of women are very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. This heterogeneity is particularly striking in women with artificial skull deformations, who appear to have originated in southeastern Europe. We also show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results provide insights into the genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages and suggest that complex demographic processes may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the cross-species transmission of MERS-CoV and other bat coronaviruses. (Show more)

This study demonstrates the feasibility of using a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a resource-scarce setting. The study also highlights the importance of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, where epidemics are likely to emerge, but where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study is a proof of concept for a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform that can be used to identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in lagging strand replication. It also provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in lagging strand replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. The RNA world is a hypothesized stage in the evolution of life, in which genetic information was encoded in RNA molecules rather than in DNA. In this paper, we report the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can synthesize functional RNA molecules from an RNA template. The improved polymerase ribozyme can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the realization of the RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of neighborhoods over time and to study the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical processes that shape cities.

The study of the immune characteristics of patients with severe coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has identified that the pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also a toxic metal that can cause severe damage to cells. The existence of a fungal copper-binding analog of the widely distributed bacterial catecholate-based siderophore, the xanthocillin family, is a surprising discovery. The existence of this copper-binding analog in fungi suggests a previously unknown role for this class of natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes.

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery.

Frost is a major environmental factor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the commonalities in the leaf-out strategies of trees across the Northern Hemisphere are a result of adaptation to the region’s frost history. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are a result of adaptation to the region’s frost frequency. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

The Th17 cell lineage is a major source of pathogenic inflammation in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease are not fully understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can contribute to the development of Th1 cells and that this process requires the expression of the transcription factor T-bet. These findings suggest that Th17 cells are not only potent initiators of inflammation but also potent effectors of disease. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease may lead to the development of new therapies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease mechanism is not fully understood. Here we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study the disease mechanism and to screen for drugs. This method will enable the study of the disease mechanism and the development of new therapies.

The role of the microbiota in the transmission of infectious agents to vectors is a rapidly emerging area of research. Here, we show that the human granulocytic anaplasmosis bacterium, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, induces the tick I. scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the transmission of Anaplasma. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiota in vector-borne disease transmission and opens up new avenues for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The study of the origin of the avian tail is a major focus of avian paleontology. The discovery of a new basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis, adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group.

We show that the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This is a significant finding because it is often assumed that the climate system is well mixed, with the exception of the stratosphere and troposphere. We show that the stratosphere is not well mixed, and that it is important for the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are green. The color of a vertebrate is determined by the absorption spectrum of its pigments, which are in turn determined by the structure of the proteins that bind them. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the color is determined by the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a compound that is formed when hemoglobin is degraded. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of green color in vertebrates. They also provide a mechanism for the evolution of new colors in vertebrates. This study is a major advance in our understanding of the evolution of color in vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene encoding a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is dependent on ALKBH5 and HIF-1α and -2α, and is associated with the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, our study identifies a mechanism by which hypoxia maintains breast cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of new therapies for breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. This paper presents a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. The results suggest that the source of the parchment for the first pocket Bibles was not unusual.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the Permian-Triassic boundary based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of inflammation and immune responses in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a major health problem, and the current treatment is limited by the lack of effective drugs. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the intestinal inflammation of IBD. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential target for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in two variants that are currently circulating. We show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent conformational changes required for membrane fusion. Our results provide a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the D614G mutant virus.

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
