COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and racial and ethnic disparities in mortality have been stark. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, and at age 65 y by 0.87 y, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are the starting point for the development of chemical models. The chemical properties of atoms are also the starting point for the development of chemical models of the properties of matter. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and that these changes are consistent with the development of a predictive model of the chemical properties of atoms. This work is a major advance in the field of chemical physics.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of fires, but the implications for the global carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, as caused by socioeconomic development, can reduce fire activity and mitigate warming. However, the risk of more extreme fires, especially in regions with high fire activity, means that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective under lower emission scenarios. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to better understand the effects of climate change on fire regimes.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to control the composition of their microbial communities. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to control the activity of a specific symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in the light-producing organ of the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the organ is actively producing light. This glycan-induced modulation of the symbiont’s activity is likely to be a general feature of animal-microbe interactions, and may be used by hosts to control the activity of their symbionts.

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly being used to understand society. However, the data are often unstructured, and it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a generative model to identify a set of latent topics that are distributed over words. We then use word embeddings to represent each topic as a vector. This vector can be interpreted as a “discourse atom” that summarizes the topic. We can then identify the topics that are most salient in a text corpus. Our method can be applied to many domains, and it can be extended to other types of data. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the mid-14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium into Europe, after which it established itself in rodent reservoirs. Our study shows that this assumption is not supported by the historical record. Instead, we find evidence for repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the establishment of the plague in Europe was a process of repeated introductions, rather than a single event. This finding has implications for our understanding of the history of the plague and its impact on European society. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, they are also a food source for a variety of predators, including sea stars, which are themselves a food source for humans and other predators. In this study, we show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of a disease that has led to the mass mortality of sea stars. This study provides a clear example of the impact of a virus on a marine ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge, and there is an urgent need for new therapies. We show here that a monoclonal antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is able to target AML stem cells and that this antibody is able to induce antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, we show that the antibody is able to block IL-1 signaling, which is important for the growth of AML cells. Thus, the antibody is able to target both AML stem cells and leukemic cells, which is important for the treatment of AML. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the island was settled by multiple waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated, and our results suggest that the island was settled by multiple independent waves. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a first step toward understanding the history of the Indian Ocean region.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, increasing its activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress the expression of two other genes. The RNA and protein compete for the same translation factors, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to control carbon utilization.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as those in vaccines and therapeutics. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work provides a promising approach for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in the US. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the CPC data are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be easily extended to other countries and crops. The proposed Crop Condition Index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be easily extended to other countries and crops.

Language processing is a complex task that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports memory for linguistic information. This mechanism is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons that are driven by the activity of the network. This adaptive process is able to store information in a form that can be accessed and processed without the need for cued retrieval. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that is based on a mechanism that is sensitive to context and serial order. It is also able to capture the effects of interference within memory. This work is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is a key uncertainty in our understanding of the future evolution of the carbon cycle. In this study, we provide a synthesis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of experimental warming. Our analysis reveals that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration does not change with warming in most biomes, but that respiration rates with and without warming follow a Gaussian response, increasing with soil temperature up to a threshold of ∼25 °C, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. These results provide a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Show more)

The origin of plastids and their subsequent evolution are among the most important questions in biology. The study of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of this research. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a hallmark of the origin of plastids, is associated with a stepwise relaxation of purifying selection on the plastid genome.

The results of this study provide a quantitative assessment of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent drought in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% by the year 2100 under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of regional climate variability in the occurrence of droughts in SSA. The results of this study are of relevance to the water resources of the region and to the global climate change community.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a naturally occurring anthropogenic quasicrystal, the first to be so dated, is a significant milestone in the history of quasicrystals.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. The oxygenic photosynthetic organisms are cyanobacteria, plants, and purple and green phototrophic bacteria. The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is the most productive biological pathway on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the evolution of the isocyclisation reaction in oxygenic photosynthetic organisms.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known that neuroinflammation is associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of disease. Our findings suggest that ASK1-mediated glial cell interactions are important in the pathophysiology of MS. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new therapies for MS. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most extreme droughts in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past few decades, and that this increase is due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology is still unknown. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. It also provides a potential target for the development of a Drosophila model of autism. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in its components are associated with a variety of human diseases. Here, we identify a number of gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which are associated with a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities, bleeding, and miosis, and in ORAI1, which is associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of miosis and tubular myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The study of the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a major focus of research. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in Drosophila is non–cell-autonomous, and that this spreading is associated with the internalization of aggregates by recipient neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, a protein involved in the fusion of synaptic vesicles. These results provide a model for the study of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as important reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats and found that this protein is a potent immunomodulator that inhibits the antiviral immune response and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this immunomodulator. These findings may help to elucidate the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats and provide a basis for the development of novel antiviral strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the one-carbon unit derived from the folate cycle. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that these inhibitors are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell cancers. We also show that one-carbon unit deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, we have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of serine hydroxymethyltransferase, and have identified a metabolic deficiency of one-carbon unit deficiency in cancer. This deficiency is targetable, and may be a useful therapeutic target.

The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the brain and spinal cord of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) suggests that the disease is associated with a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. This metastable state is lost in the context of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis, leading to the formation of inclusions. The presence of inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS suggests that the disease is associated with a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a rationale for the presence of coaggregating proteins in the inclusions of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be used to study many-body physics of quantum matter, including the study of topological phases and the emergence of supersolids.

The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral DNA in the archaeological record. Here we present the first ancient viral genomes from the archaeological record, which provide insights into the evolution of viruses and the history of human populations.

Sea level is a key indicator of climate change because it is sensitive to both ocean mass and water density. We show that the acceleration of sea level over the last 25 y is not random but is consistent with a climate-change–driven signal. This result is important because it provides a more precise estimate of the climate-change–driven acceleration of sea level than has been available previously.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity that is key to understanding the reaction pathway and the role of the cofactor in catalysis.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. The disease has a high case fatality rate, and there is no specific antiviral treatment. We show that the broad-spectrum antiviral remdesivir, which is in clinical use for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This suggests that remdesivir may be a useful treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to control the composition of their microbial communities. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to control the activity of a specific symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in the light-producing organ of the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the organ is actively producing light. This glycan-induced modulation of the symbiont’s activity is likely to be a general feature of animal-microbe interactions, and may be used by hosts to control the activity of their symbionts.

This paper reports on a series of experiments that tested whether teachers’ mindsets about discipline could be changed through a scalable intervention. We found that teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions, and that these mindsets can be changed through scalable intervention. This work has implications for the future of education, as well as for the future of the criminal justice system.

DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage and mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkyl

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV tropism, and therefore may be a significant determinant of MERS-CoV virulence.

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased. This finding has implications for the food service industry, policymakers, and the general public. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings could be a simple and effective way to help people make more sustainable dietary choices. This approach could be particularly effective in high-income countries, where the proportion of vegetarian meals available is currently low. The results also suggest that it may be possible to achieve a rebound effect, where the proportion of vegetarian meals available leads to an increase in the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased. This study provides a clear demonstration of the potential of nudging to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings. The results suggest that this approach could be a useful tool for policymakers and the food service industry in the pursuit of more sustainable diets.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. This interface is a major target for cancer therapy, and the surfaceome is a major target for drug discovery. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the surfaceome of a breast cancer cell line expressing oncogenes, and show that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with a glycoproteomics approach, and show that oncogenes have a major impact on the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a major advance in the field of cancer surfaceome and glycoproteome research. It will be a major resource for cancer biomarker and drug discovery. It will also be a major resource for the study of other oncogenic processes such as viral infection.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the molecular basis of viral pathogenesis. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique architecture that may contribute to the immune evasion and immune evasion activities observed in this virus.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of many diseases, including cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is associated with the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), which in turn contributes to the development of edema. Our study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia, and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (PsycINFO Database Record

The world is full of associations. We live in an era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We are often interested in the strength of these associations. However, the fact that we have “cherry-picked”—searched for the strongest associations—means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This paper describes some recent developments in selective inference and illustrates their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help researchers to better understand the strengths and limitations of their methods.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells is still a challenge. Here, we show that the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the generation of endothelial cells from nonvascular cells. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. It also provides a new direction for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The identification of “orphan” RTKs has led to the discovery of their physiological ligands. This work demonstrates that the zebrafish augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of cell that is responsible for the production of the zebrafish chromatophores. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and the Ltk RTK and demonstrate that the augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores in a tissue-specific context. This work provides a model system for the study of the function of orphan RTKs and their ligands. It also provides a model for the study of the role of RTKs in the development of specialized cells. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem, and the molecular mechanisms underlying its development are still poorly understood. Herein, we show that the STING signaling pathway plays a critical role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. This mechanism is likely to limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses.

The present study provides evidence that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical mechanism for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our study also identifies a potential therapeutic target for the prevention of atherosclerosis. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention of atherosclerosis.

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that humans have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that this expansion is largely due to human activities. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of neighborhoods over time and to study the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical underpinnings of urban change.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insects. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of arthropod–plant adaptation. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid rise of viremia, the presence of a short eclipse phase, and the rapid clearance of ZIKV. We also provide estimates of the parameters of the model, which can be used to guide future studies. Finally, we provide estimates of the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to clearance of ZIKV. These estimates can be used to guide the design of clinical trials. (Read more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, yet they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In particular, the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis caused by heat stress is considered to be the most important driver of the ongoing decline of coral reefs worldwide. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that is involved in a wide range of physiological processes, including the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also a site of tumorigenesis, and that the tumor microenvironment is able to influence the composition and activity of the intestinal microbiome. We identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can influence the growth of intestinal tumors, and highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the interaction between the intestinal epithelium and its microbiome, and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of intestinal tumors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death among women in the United States. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is often poor. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 is a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is not supported by a comprehensive analysis of the available paleoclimate data. We show that a unique volcanic eruption series, coincident with the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a climate response that is consistent with the observed deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which can be used to assess the impacts of fishing on biodiversity and food security. We find that freshwater fisheries are concentrated in regions of high poverty and food insecurity, and that fishing pressure is highest in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our data can be used to identify the locations of productive fisheries and the populations that depend on them, and can be integrated into environmental planning to protect biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of the material is the key to achieve high energy density and long cycle life. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of energy storage.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control this capacity are not well understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway known to control regeneration in the nervous system. This discovery has implications for the study of regeneration in the nervous system, as well as for the treatment of neurological disorders.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the evolution of genomes and the function of genes. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that of a mouse model of a positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9 mutation. We find that the distribution of recombination in plants and mice is similar, suggesting that the initiation of recombination in eukaryotes may have been conserved over a long period of evolution.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the generation of cognitive functions. The present study provides a method to identify and validate the resting state organization of the brain, based on the analysis of metabolic imaging. This method can be used to identify the organization of the brain in health and disease.

This paper describes a 5′ cap structure in yeast that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). This cap is found on a subset of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and is not found on the corresponding pre-mRNAs. The existence of this cap raises the possibility that it could modulate the stability and translation of specific classes of mRNA.

The study of epigenetic mechanisms has led to the discovery of the role of DNA methylation in the regulation of gene expression. In this study, we show that DNA methylation patterns at specific loci in blood cells are associated with glycemia in the past and with the progression of complications in the present. These findings support the role of epigenetic mechanisms in the metabolic memory observed in people with diabetes. This study also provides a possible explanation for the mechanisms by which the effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on complications in people with diabetes persist for several years. This study is also relevant for the study of other chronic diseases, such as cardiovascular disease, where epigenetic mechanisms are also involved. (PsycINFO Database Record
This study provides a mechanism for the role of FSIP1 in the drug sensitivity of TNBC. Our findings may aid in the design of therapies for TNBC.

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. The present study shows that the gut microbiota is altered in alcohol dependence and that some of the changes are associated with the development of gut leakiness and with the severity of psychological symptoms. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, which are responsible for the characteristic aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not well understood, and the role of nitrogenous compounds in tomato flavor is still unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase, which catalyzes the formation of nitrogenous volatiles from their corresponding precursors. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. It also opens the door to the development of new tomato varieties with improved flavor. (Read more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the impacts of these two factors on ecosystem functioning are not independent, but rather that the additional impacts of warming on the biodiversity–functioning relationship are amplified by the thermal tolerance traits of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and suggest that the additional impacts of warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a hub of the hippocampal circuit, which is critical for spatial memory. The organization of its neurons is important for understanding the circuit’s function. Here, we show that the neurons of the MEC are organized into distinct layers, and that the neurons in each layer are organized into distinct groups. We also show that the neurons in the MEC are organized into distinct groups, and that the groups are organized into layers.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FT gene of Cuscuta australis is not required for flowering of the host plant. Instead, we show that the FT protein of the parasite is able to move into the host plant and interact with a host transcription factor to induce flowering of the host. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model system for studying the flowering regulation of dodder. View Full-Text

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra form specialized arborizations that are not only important for the transmission of dopamine to other brain regions but also for the integration of information within the dopamine system itself. These findings have implications for our understanding of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We all know when we’re feeling connected to someone, but how do we know when two people are feeling connected to each other? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. The SAN is a highly coordinated network of cells that is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. This study reveals that the stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells, which contributes to the automaticity of the SAN. These studies provide a better understanding of the mechanisms that govern the generation of the heartbeat. (Show more)

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented. However, the role of silicon in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been well studied. In this study, we show that silicon pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, by promoting the accumulation of silicon in rice leaves and by increasing the expression of genes involved in defense responses. These results suggest that silicon may be used as a tool to improve plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

This study provides a new perspective on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. It also reveals a central role of alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and demonstrates that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language processing is a complex task that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the duration of memory. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the duration of memory. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the delivery of biomolecules to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the development of plant-based therapies. (Show more)

Nutrient inputs to coastal ecosystems are often dominated by a small number of large tributaries. However, the role of smaller tributaries in coastal nutrient loading has been largely overlooked. We show that the majority of the daily nutrient loads delivered to Lake Michigan by its tributaries are from a small number of large tributaries. However, the nutrient loads from smaller tributaries are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that small watersheds may play a greater role in fueling coastal algal blooms than previously thought. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in coastal nutrient loading and provide a framework for targeting nutrient management efforts to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “optimal brain damage” strategy of the neuroscientist Donald O. Hebb, which aims to maximize the complexity of the brain by minimizing the number of connections between its neurons. Our results suggest that the brain may have evolved to minimize the number of connections between its chemical sensors and effectors, thus increasing the complexity of its information processing.

This study provides a detailed description of the mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. The study also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of encephalitis on the brain’s electrical activity. This work is expected to help in the development of new therapies for patients with this disease.

The history of Earth’s climate is a history of abrupt warming events. These events are often associated with changes in the carbon cycle, which is the focus of this study. We present a detailed analysis of a major carbon cycle perturbation that occurred during a global warming event. The event is associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We show that the event can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean. This carbon is likely to have been derived from the subduction of organic-rich sediments and the decomposition of marine organic matter. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms that control the timing and magnitude of carbon cycle perturbations and global warming events. They also provide a possible explanation for the origin of the Burgess Shale, a famous fossil assemblage from the Canadian Rockies that contains many of the most ancient complex animals.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of deforestation in Indonesia, a major source of greenhouse gas emissions. We show that certification of palm oil by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) has reduced deforestation in Indonesia. However, certification has not yet had a large impact on the forest cover remaining in oil palm plantations. We also show that certification has not reduced fire in oil palm plantations. Our results suggest that certification has not yet had a large impact on deforestation and fire in Indonesia, and that certification has not yet had a large impact on forest cover remaining in oil palm plantations.

The exocyst complex is a well-conserved protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms of life. However, the molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex and its regulation are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and its role in human diseases. It also offers a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a major focus of evolutionary research. In this study, we show that the genetic basis of sex can have a major impact on the evolution of secondary sexual traits.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species. These species are generated by the metabolism of vitamin A and can damage the retina. We show that the presence of iron in the retina can promote the oxidation and degradation of these species. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the retina’s response to iron and may lead to the development of new therapies for retinal diseases.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that specialization can be maintained in a modular way, as in the case of siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians that use tentilla (tentacle side branches armed with nematocysts) exclusively for prey capture. Our results help to understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also contribute to the development of a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The hominin hand is a complex of bones that has been the focus of intense study for more than a century. The fossil record of the hominin hand is incomplete, however, and the origin of some of the most distinctive features of the modern human hand is not well understood. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study thus contributes to our understanding of the evolution of the hominin hand and its relationship to the Neandertal hand. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the one-carbon unit derived from the folate cycle. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which converts serine to glycine and a folate cycle intermediate. We show that these inhibitors are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell cancers. We also show that one-carbon unit deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, we have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of a key metabolic enzyme, and have identified a targetable metabolic deficiency of a cancer type. This work represents a significant advance in the development of cancer therapeutics.

This study provides evidence of the impact of deforestation on people’s diets in rural Tanzania. The results show that deforestation has a negative impact on people’s diets, which is likely to have implications for their vitamin A status. The results also show that forest fragmentation has a positive impact on people’s diets, which is likely to have implications for their vitamin A status. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a modeling approach to test causal hypotheses, which is rarely done in nutrition research. We believe that this study will be of interest to researchers and policy makers alike.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for higher output of food and other agricultural products. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the fact that the largest sauropods, the brachiosaurs, had the largest footprints, which are consistent with the idea of roaming over fixed trails. Our results suggest that the ecological strategies of sauropods may have guided the design of their mechanical equivalents. This is a significant finding, as it suggests that the design of farm machinery may have been guided by the ecological strategies of the dinosaurs.
